I was born on July 12 100 BCE in Rome to the prestigious but politically modest Julian family, which claims descent from the goddess Venus.
I grew up during the turbulent era of Marius and Sulla, and my family's ties to Marius put me in danger when Sulla serized control forcing me into temporary exile.
As a young man, I briefly served in Asia Minor, where I earned the Civic Crown for bravery after saving the life of a fellow soldier.
In 75 BCE, I was captured by Cilician pirates, where I famously insisted they raise my ranson and I later returned with a fleet to capture and execute them.
I began my political rise as a military tribune and later quaestor in 69 BCE, which initiated my formal path up the cursus honorum.
I served as governor of Hispania Ulterior in 61-60 BCE, where my military successes helped me build prestige.
In 60 BCE, I formed the First Triumvirate with Pompey the Great and Crassus, an informal power alliance that dominated Roman politics.
I was elected consul in 59 BCE, using my position to pass land reforms and strengthen ties with Pompey through political maneuvering and marriage alliances.
I married three times, to Cornelia, Pompeia, and Calpurnia, but my longest standing romantic partnership was with Cleopatra VII of Egypt.
I was the the father of at least one confirmed child, Ptolemy XV Caesarion, born from my relationship with Cleopatra in 47 BCE, but i did not publicly recognise him as mine.
I was known for my charm and oratory, which aided my political rise and helped me maintain alliances and popularity among both elites and commoners.
Although criticized for my ambition, I cultivated loyalty through generosity, famously forgiving former enemies during my rule as dictator.
My conquest of Gaul (58-80 BCE) expanded Roman territory to the Atlantic Ocean and brought me immense wealth and military loyalty.
I defeated the Helvetii, Belgae, and various Gallic coalitions, culminating in the decisive victory over Vercingetorix at the Siege of Alesia in 52 BCE.
I led two expeditions to Britain in 55 and 54 BCE, marking the first Roman military contact with the British Isles.
My civil war (49-45 BCE) began when I crossed the Rubicon River in 49 BCE, defeating Pompey's forces at battles such as Pharsalus (48 BCE) and later consolidating power across the Roman world.
I authored 'Commentarii de Bello Gallico,' a detailed, third-person account of my campaigns in Gaul, used to enhance my image in Rome.
I wrote 'Commentarii de Bello Civili,' describing the civil war against Pompey with a narrative portraying myself as reluctant but justified.
My writing was praised for my clear, direct Latin prose style, which became a model for later historians and students.
Some of my lesser-known works, including speeches or poems, survive only in fragments or references by later authors.
I had significant impact on Roman culture, promoting public games, building projects, and the restructuring of the calendar.
I reformed the Roman Calendar in 46 BCE, creating the Julian calendar, which served as the basis for the modern Gregorian calendar.
I encouraged the blending of Roman and foreign customs, especially through my alliances with regions like Egypt.
My public image was widely promoted through statues, coins, and triumphal celebrations, establishing a model for imperial propaganda later used by emperors.
I was assassinated on March 15 44 BCE by a group of senators including Brutus, Cassius, and more than 20 conspirators.
The conspirators claimed they acted to restore the Republic, fearing my growing power and my recent appointment as dictator perpetuo.
My funeral in the Roman Forum triggered massive public unrest, leading to riots and the eventual flight of several assassins.
My death sparked another civil war, culminating in the rise of my adopted heir Octavian (later Augustus) and the transition from Republic to Empire.
My name became synonymous with power, giving rise to titles such as 'Kaiser' in Germany and 'Tsar' in Russia.
My military strategies are still studied today, especially my use of engineering, rapid mobility, and phychological warfare.
My influence persists in literature, theater, and popular culture, with Shakespeare's 'Julius Caesar' being one of the most well-known dramatization of my life.
